entry.title: SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Why this matters: the upcoming changes turn what looked like a technical switch into a strategic decision that can affect your budget, compliance posture, and HCM roadmap. Activations of Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA directly influence whether you need additional HCM licenses, which capabilities you can keep on-premise versus in Private Cloud, and how quickly you should plan a move to SuccessFactors for certain functions. Getting ahead of this now helps you avoid unplanned costs or audit exposure, prevents disruption to HR processes tied to payroll, time, and regulatory reporting, and gives you time to align contracts, license product codes, and project timelines. The guidance below distills what’s changing and the practical steps to stay compliant while keeping your transformation on track.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA  will be turned on by default. From this release on, there is no compatibility pack for HCM anymore.  This technical change is not reversible. The licensing requirements are applicable when SAP HCM is utilized beyond the scope of the HR Mini Master, in cases where the customer is conducting HCM processes in the system.

For the technical details, please check the KBA 3443536 - SAP S/4HANA Release 2025 will be delivered with active H4S4_1 Business Function - SAP for Me 

Some functionality is not available in S/4HANA Private Cloud; e.g. SAP Learning Solution is available in S/4HANA on-premise, when moving to Private Cloud, the go-to solution is SuccessFactors Learning.

You can see the details of what features are enabled and what are disabled you can check in the following note 3091160 - SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA – General Approach and Strategy - SAP for Me 

A customer using the HCM compatibility pack today in SAP S/4HANA on-premise can receive a prolongation only if they move to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, via a lift-and-shift (like-for-like) migration that preserves the current release. If the move includes an upgrade to the 2025 release, the H4S4_1 business function will be active by default, and the HCM compatibility pack will no longer be available, so prolongation does not apply.  With the requested change, they would get the prolongation as well in case they directly move to SuccessFactors, which is our strategic intent.

HCM License Materials and Usage Rights 

Customers must also license SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA, at the latest, the first day after the expiry of the Compatibility Package.

Please contact your account executive to plan the license conversion as soon as possible. 

I hope you found this blog post helpful. If you did, please give it a "like" or share it. I’d love to hear your thoughts and feedback, so feel free to leave a comment. If you have any questions, just drop them in the Q&A section with the tags SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We'll try to get back to you as soon as we can.


Thanks,

entry.title: How to perform a successful Carve-Out in SAP ECC and S/4HANA – Update and New Trends 2025 (Part I)
entry.content:
It has been four years since I published my original five-part series on SAP Carve-Outs - covering basic topics from what a carve out is (Part I), data migration (Part II) and technical orchestration (Part III) to process and analytics considerations (Part IV) and S/4HANA value creation (Part V).

Time for a look back on what has changed since then with new trends for SAP Carve-Outs and Divestiture Projects in business and technology.

The good news is: The core principles and methods outlined in those earlier posts remain as relevant today as they were then.

However, the past four years have brought notable shifts in both business dynamics and technology landscapes, reshaping how carve-out projects must be planned, managed, and executed. In many cases, these changes have introduced greater complexity, requiring organizations to adapt their strategies to ensure success.

From our recent project experience and industry observations, two main drivers stand out:

  1. More complex M&A scenarios – including multi-entity, multi-source, and joint-venture carve-outs, often with heightened compliance and harmonization requirements.
  2. Technology disruption – particularly the accelerated move to the cloud and the looming SAP ECC end-of-maintenance deadlines (2027, or 2030 with costly extended maintenance under SAP RISE).

In this update, I will explore these emerging trends from two perspectives:

Business & M&A Scenario-Driven Trends (Part I):

  • Harmonization of processes and structures during the carve-out to reduce operational complexity post-transition.
  • Multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs that combine data from different systems into a consolidated environment.
  • Enhanced compliance and legal alignment to address stricter regulatory and contractual requirements.
  • Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go-live to keep operations running seamlessly and without any business disruption

Technology-Driven Trends (Part II):

  • Move to cloud – whether via hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) in private hosting, or through SAP RISE and GROW with SAP offerings.
  • Expanded functional and integration scope – including SAP modules, third-party systems (Salesforce, Ariba, IBP, EDI), and rebuilt analytics landscapes.
  • Combined carve-out and S/4HANA transformation to deliver a modern, value-enhanced system to the buyer.
  • Custom code carve-out and clean-core modernization to simplify future operations and reduce technical debt.

Both parts of this post build on the foundation of the original series, now enriched with current project examples and the latest industry best practices - offering a forward-looking view of what it takes to execute a successful carve-out in 2025 and beyond.

 

Business and M&A Scenario–Driven Trends in Modern SAP Carve-Outs

1. Harmonization of Processes and Structures

In recent years, we have seen a growing emphasis on harmonizing processes and organizational structures during carve-outs – especially to reduce operational complexity after the transition. This is particularly common among private equity buyers, who aim to simplify process variants, adopt industry best practices over heavy customization, and standardize reporting structures across multiple acquisitions. Two main approaches are used:

Option 1: Greenfield Implementation in the Public Cloud

Some buyers opt for a brand-new SAP system - often in an SAP GROW public cloud environment - built entirely on standardized, industry best-practice processes.

  • Advantages: Fast to implement, provides a clean slate, and allows extensions via SAP BTP without burdening the core system.
  • Caveats:
    • Historic data is typically lost, requiring separate archival for audit or business purposes.
    • The “big bang” cutover into entirely new processes can disrupt business operations without strong change management.

This approach is best suited for asset deals or acquisitions of smaller, less complex entities.

Option 2: Selective Data Transition (SDT)

With the right Transformation Software, SDT enables you to migrate only selected data while simultaneously transforming processes, configurations, and structures. For example, in a carve-out involving multiple company codes from a highly integrated environment, intercompany relationships may need to be converted into customer-vendor-structures - requiring both process reconfiguration and master/transactional data transformation.

SDT also allows:

  • Changing charts of accounts, profit/cost centers, plants, and org structures.
  • Transforming open and historical transactional data to match new processes.
  • Maintaining a continuity of historical data in the new environment.

Trade-offs: SDT is more complex, typically requiring 6-12 months for high-complexity projects and demanding greater involvement from both IT and business teams.

We have seen SDT increasingly used in share deals, spin-offs, and large-scale asset divestitures with significant process complexity.

 

2. Multi-Source & Joint-Venture Carve-Outs

Another fast-growing trend involves multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs, where data from multiple ERP systems must be consolidated into one new environment.

Typical scenarios:

  • Multi-source carve-out: Extracting data from several ERP systems (ECC, S/4HANA, or both) within the same organization, often during ongoing SAP S/4HANA transformation projects.
  • Joint-venture setup: Merging data and processes from multiple partners into a shared system.

Challenges include:

  • Harmonizing master data, processes, charts of accounts, and org structures – including historic transactional data.
  • Managing licensing and data visibility between different corporate owners.
  • Separating and rebuilding formerly shared subsystems or third-party integrations.

Given their complexity, these projects nearly always use SDT combined with system merge methodologies, cross-system harmonization, and automation for plant or unit reallocation - while ensuring strict data access controls between Joint-Venture partners.

Additionally, these projects require a significant engagement from SAP specialists to adjust and reshape processes, harmonize data and organizaional structures, properly adjust interfaces to external or cloud-based systems, and enhance data analytics and reporting. Due to the variety of skill sets needed and the urgency in a carve-out project, the setup usually requires engaging with a specialized System Integrator (SI) early in the project planning phase to ensure these topics are successfully covered.

 

3. Enhanced Compliance & Legal Alignment

Stricter regulations and geopolitical constraints now significantly influence carve-out planning and execution.

Examples include:

  • GDPR for companies doing business in EU-countries
  • Industry-specific requirements (e.g., regulated industries like Utilities, Aerospace & Defense).
  • Data sovereignty laws such as China’s DSL, CSL, and PIPL, which can require a separate, localized SAP system, to protect your global business data by keeping it separate.

Implications:

  • Migrate only approved data subsets, particularly personal data.
  • Ensure full audit documentation of extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Include technical safeguards such as log tracing, reversible deletions, and cutover checks.

Modern SDT Software products - like cbs ET Enterprise Transformer - already offer audit-grade logging for these processes, making compliance easier to prove post-project.

 

Vendor landscape Note:

In the context of the SDT approach, it is worth noting that only four vendors worldwide currently provide both the specialized SDT software and the associated service capabilities needed for complex carve-out scenarios. All are members of the SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement Program and typically collaborate with other system integrators (SI) to cover the full range of services required.

At present, only one of these vendors is able to deliver the complete end-to-end service portfolio independently - an advantage that means fewer communication gaps, with consultants who understand the full scope of services and the role of SDT in the project, rather than working in isolated silos.

Given the sustained market demand for SDT-based initiatives - including both carve-outs and broader SAP S/4HANA transformation projects - delivery capacity can become a bottleneck. To mitigate this risk, organizations should secure delivery slots as early as possible, ideally before the transaction is finalized and the Transition Services Agreement (TSA) is signed, to ensure the resource availability and alignment with agreed project timelines.

 

4. Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go/live

A successful carve-out is not just about getting the technical cutover right - it’s equally about ensuring the carved-out organization can operate smoothly from day one. One of the most significant risks during these projects is operational disruption, which both buyer and seller are highly motivated to avoid before, during, and after the system handover. Maintaining stable business operations has increasingly become therefore a central project goal.

Change Management and Training

Beyond ensuring clean, accurate data in the new system, it is critical to prepare the business workforce for changes to their daily processes and routines. This requires structured change management and targeted training in all areas where processes are being redesigned or where new roles and responsibilities are introduced. This becomes even more important when moving to more standardized, harmonized processes - often with fewer customization and a leaner user interface than in the previous environment.

In such cases, acceptance grows when users understand the why behind the change and are given the tools and guidance to confidently perform their work in the new system. Proper preparation minimizes post–go-live disruption and supports long-term adoption.

Application Management Services (AMS)

In recent years, we have seen a strong trend toward integrating AMS into carve-out project scope from the outset. This is particularly relevant when:

  • The carved-out entity lacks internal SAP expertise after organizational changes or downsizing post-transaction.
  • The seller’s IT services under the TSA come at a premium, and the buyer seeks a faster, more cost-effective transition away from them.
  • The buyer needs a bridging solution until a new internal IT team is in place.

Some AMS providers even offer fractional consulting for small-scale enhancements and process improvements after go-live, adding flexibility during the stabilization phase.

Choosing a provider who delivers AMS as part of a comprehensive business transformation has clear advantages, as they understand carve-out–specific requirements such as altered team responsibilities, new support structures, and heightened service continuity needs.

For smaller and mid-sized organizations, SAP’s M&A Ambassador Program can be a valuable option, particularly for PE-driven carve-outs. It equips these projects with expert partner frameworks to manage both the initial deployment and post-go-live stabilization. Unfortunately, this program does not include any provider with SDT capabilities.

Recommendation: Define AMS scope and contracts early - including infrastructure operations, interface monitoring, patching, SLA targets, and knowledge handover - so that post-go-live operations run as smoothly as the cutover itself.

 

Summary of Part I and Key Takeaways

Over the past years, my team and I have seen, and experienced with our customers, that carve-outs in 2025 are no longer purely IT-driven exercises.They are strategic business transformations requiring early leadership engagement and precise planning.

On the business side, the key success factors are:

  • Early preparation: Business readiness and TSA alignment before signing prevent costly delays.
  • Selective Data Transition (SDT) as a game changer: Enabling selective migration and process harmonization with minimal disruption; early partner selection is crucial given limited global capacity.
  • Integrated service delivery: One provider delivering end-to-end reduces communication gaps and ensures holistic understanding.
  • Business continuity protection: Early investment in process mapping, change management, and training ensures smoother cutovers.
  • Built-in stabilization: Integrating AMS from the onset speeds post–go-live recovery.
  • Organizational change management: Early engagement drives faster adoption and productivity.

For the technical delivery models, toolsets, and SDT-related innovations shaping carve-outs in 2025 and beyond, see Part II of this Update 2025 post.

If you’d like to discuss your own carve-out scenario, feel free to contact me directly. @Lorenz_Praefcke2

entry.title: Standard Integration Packages Plug-and-Play for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 and ESM and Utlities
entry.content:
In today's growing CRM demand faster, more agile implementations with minimal overhead. SAP understands this need and has responded with a new generation of standard integration packages for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2, specially tailored for industries such as Utilities and Enterprise Service Management (ESM). These pre-packaged solutions are designed for plug-and-play integration, eliminating the need for extensive customization and ensuring rapid deployment and value realization.

Why Standard Integration Packages?

Traditionally, integration projects have required significant customization, consulting hours, and effort. This often led to increased costs, longer go-live timelines, and higher maintenance overhead. Standard integration packages reverse this model by offering:

  • Preconfigured scenarios
  • Best practice processes
  • Certified integration content
  • Zero or minimal customization requirements

These benefits help organizations streamline operations, reduce IT complexity, and accelerate time-to-value.

Key Features of the Standard Integration Packages

1. Out-of-the-Box Integration

SAP provides prebuilt connectors and iFlows using SAP Integration Suite (formerly CPI) to integrate SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 with ESM solutions (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Service) and utility backends (e.g., IS-U, S/4HANA Utilities).

2. Industry-Specific Scenarios

These packages cater specifically to industry needs:

  • Utilities: Handle meter-to-cash processes, service request handling, complaint management, and field service coordination.
  • ESM: Manage enterprise-wide service requests, knowledge bases, approvals, and fulfillment workflows.

3. Certified Integration Content

All integration content is:

  • Published in the SAP API Business Hub
  • Regularly updated and maintained by SAP
  • Based on SAP Best Practices and aligned with standard APIs

entry.title: “Business Excellence with SAP’s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How”
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes – Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration – Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility – Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data – Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations – Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the “Extensibility” guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via “Side-by-side” extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through “S/4 HANA On-stack” extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple “clean vs. not clean” classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. It’s about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesn’t come at the cost of technical debt.

Here’s what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices – Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions – Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Build—all supported by Joule, SAP’s AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure – Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API is—because most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A – The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released API’s and extension points.

Level B –Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C – Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D – Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The “SAP Business Accelerator Hub” and “Cloudification Repository (API Viewer)” are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C – default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP’s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in “On-stack extensibility”.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public” and “SAP S/4HANA Private Edition” for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of “S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API’s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API’s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Released” under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on “Object type”, “Software Component” and “Application Component”

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “purchase_order”)

4.2 Extension Level B – Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API’s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Classic API” in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “sales”)

4.3 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither “Released APIs,” “Classical APIs,” nor “APIs” at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level D – Not Clean Core

Extensions at level D are classified as not clean core. These includes extensions that doesn’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are “Not APIs” classified as “No APIs”

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar

3. Choose “No API” in State

4. Results with “No APIs” are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt—while still getting the flexibility they need today.

entry.title: Unpacking the new SAP Business Suite
entry.content:
This blog intends to provide a quick explanation of the newly announced SAP Business Suite. The blog contains the latest information as of August 26th 2025.

In February 2025, SAP announced the new SAP Business Suite (https://www.sap.com/events/business-unleashed.html), which was also covered in detail at our prime SAP SAPPHIRE events in Orlando, Madrid, and all the SAP Now events around the world. But you might be wondering what the new SAP Business Suite is.

Simply put, the SAP Business Suite helps our customers drive business innovation to achieve more valuable business outcomes in a constantly changing economy—by uniting core SAP business applications, data, and Business AI capabilities.

New SAP Business Suite

The SAP Business Suite is not simply a harmonization of release and maintenance schedules for SAP’s portfolio of solutions. It serves as a transformation engine, helping customers generate rapid cycles of innovation and continuous improvement as a service. This enables organizations to deliver greater business value and achieve improved outcomes through end-to-end processes.

SAP’s Business Suite applications (like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Concur, etc.) and SAP Business Technology Platform aren’t just siloed applications; they are integrated along end to end business process, supporting you in every business decision and outcome. This integration ensures that every action taken within these applications generates trusted, business-critical data at its source.

Within the SAP Business Suite, we have also integrated the SAP Business Data Cloud. The SAP Business Data Cloud was also announced in February 2025 . The SAP Business Data Cloud centralizes, harmonizes, and enriches the data produced by the SAP applications and non-SAP applications. So the SAP Business Data Cloud helps us unify data into a single source of truth. Now if this data is contextualized, reliable, and accessible, this data becomes the fuel for advanced AI-driven insights. SAP Business AI, included in the SAP Business Suite, goes beyond basic automation. Through SAP Joule, our AI copilot and the embedded AI capabilities in our applications, employees can orchestrate intelligent agents to collaborate across functions or get enhanced scenarios to increase productivity. This strategy breaks down silos, driving real-time, cross-enterprise optimization. We know our customers are deploying AI in isolated projects, but with our SAP Business Suite strategy, we weave it throughout your organization, unlocking value and resilience at scale.

Let’s get practical and explain how our customers consume the SAP Business Suite as a service. Next, I will cover the new SAP Business Suite Packages and the journey our customers can follow to implement them.

SAP has created buying center-based packages which provide our customers with defined functional capabilities within our core applications portfolio, data, and Business AI.  The idea is that the package can provide all the necessary capabilities for this buying center and its teams to carry out their responsibilities.

New buying center-based SAP Business Suite Packages

Now, SAP is providing two journeys for our customers so they can consume the SAP Business Suite as a service. The journeys are RISE with SAP and GROW with SAP. Before the February 2025 announcement, RISE with SAP was focused on our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and GROW with SAP was focused on our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Customer Journeys to New SAP Business Suite

Following the introduction of the SAP Business Suite, we have evolved our programs and made several enhancements to the commercial packages supporting these journeys to better serve our customers.

RISE with SAP is a journey focused on existing SAP ERP on-premise customers who are looking to modernize their legacy systems with SAP Business Suite, while GROW with SAP is a journey focused on new SAP ERP customers looking to start fresh with SAP Business Suite.

We also made changes to some names to group our solutions. We now refer to everything relevant to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and its extended capabilities offered in the SAP Business Suite Packages as "SAP Cloud ERP," and everything relevant to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and the extended capabilities offered in the SAP Business Suite Packages as "SAP Cloud ERP Private."

Now, how do we align the SAP Business Suite packages with the customer journeys?  In the figure, you can see that customers have options depending on their SAP journey and buying center. These packages can also be consumed by buying center or brought together for the entire company and buying centers. If you would like to learn more about our packages and what is included, I suggest you visit this link: https://www.sap.com/products/business-suite/pricing.html

Buying center-based packages that enable customer journeys to the new SAP Business Suite

In this blog, I want to focus more on the journeys and packages that have traditionally covered ERP functionalities by highlighting the CIO buying center and the needs of a company-wide system, including other C-suite buying centers who rely on ERP as a comprehensive solution to streamline the introduction of this concept. I won’t cover other subscriptions like add-ons, data product packages, and AI packages included in the SAP Business Suite, etc., to keep it simple and easy to understand.

Let's begin with Cloud ERP Private. This package is designed to provide customers with tailored-to-fit functionality, a very flexible system in which they maintain the governance of the system while SAP supports operations.

Here, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition is included; however, this package encompasses many more capabilities and components compared to traditional ERP (SAP ERP 6.0). The following components are included:

Components included in Cloud ERP Private Package - This content is subject to change. For the most current details, please refer to the link below

The SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages include many different SAP components supporting the CFO and COO buying centers in running their business responsibilities. Here is where you find SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a system designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, with rapid and agile innovation cycles, operated and governed by SAP.

Each of these packages includes two types of sub-packages: Base and Premium. The idea is to provide customers with flexibility when deciding on the main capabilities for each buying center. Below, I present the capabilities of the two packages:

Components included in SAP Finance Package - This content is subject to change. For the most current details, please refer to the link below

Components included in SAP Supply Chain Package - This content is subject to change. For the most current details, please refer to the link below

As you can see from the packages, the entitlements provided encompass more comprehensive capabilities and components compared to the standalone SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, offering greater business benefits and functional features.

To view the current packages and included latest capabilities, please refer to: https://www.sap.com/products/business-suite/pricing.html

Sample Customer Journeys:

SAP ERP 6.0 customer looking to move to the new SAP Business Suite.

This customer will use the RISE with SAP customer journey to move to the new SAP Business Suite. Here, the customer will have the option to select between various packages depending on their business needs. Considering that this customer runs full capabilities (FI-CO, SD, MM, PP, QM, etc.) in SAP ERP 6.0, below are the choices:

Customer Journey – RISE with SAP – Final Destination SAP Business Suite

SAP will support the customer with the selection of the right packages by using the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment (SAP DDA). The SAP DDA helps the customer assess functional needs and provides recommendations accordingly. However, it is important to note that the packages are meant to serve two distinct business purposes: Cloud ERP Private—tailored-to-fit functionality with a highly flexible system where the customer maintains governance while SAP supports operations—and SAP Finance & SAP Supply Chain, which is designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, featuring rapid and agile innovation cycles, and operated and governed by SAP.  While the SAP DDA assesses functional requirements, the customer must decide on their main strategy: whether to implement and operate their systems with a tailored-to-fit solution or embrace a fit-to-standard model.

SAP Digital Discovery Assessment

Now let's talk a bit more in detail about the journey based on the package selection.

Cloud ERP Private – An SAP ERP 6.0 customer needs tailored-to-fit functionality, with a very flexible system in which they maintain governance of the system while SAP supports operations. This customer has selected the Cloud ERP Private Package. Here, they first need to plan their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition from SAP ERP 6.0 using one of the known transition paths: New Implementation, Selective Data Transition, or System Conversion. They will benefit from the use of transformation tools and services included in the package and can also take advantage of the other components included in the package.

With the help of the transformation tools included in the package, in conjunction with the RISE with SAP methodology, we recommend that our customers pursue a clean core strategy, so they can remain technically ready in a cost-effective manner to be agile to consume new SAP innovations.

Customer Journey – RISE with SAP – Final Destination SAP Business Suite via Cloud ERP Private Package

SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages – An SAP ERP 6.0 customer decided on a state-of-the-art system designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, with rapid and agile innovation cycles and operated and governed by SAP. This customer has selected the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages. Here, they first need to plan their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition from SAP ERP 6.0 using a New Implementation. They will benefit from using SAP Activate, the SAP Signavio Process Navigator, and SAP Cloud ALM to drive their implementation, and can also take advantage of the other components included in the package (either base or premium).  And remember, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is clean core by definition, using cloud extensibility included in the solution to help our customers differentiate.

Customer Journey – RISE with SAP – Final Destination SAP Business Suite via SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages

To make the most of all the components included in these packages, the SAP Activate Methodology has been enhanced, and there is now a new roadmap available for provisioning SAP Business Suite Packages. I highly recommend using it to take full advantage of the additional components offered.

New SAP Activate for provisioning new SAP Business Suite Packages

New SAP customer looking to move to the new SAP Business Suite.

This customer will use the GROW with SAP customer journey to move to the new SAP Business Suite. Here, the customer will be defaulted to the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain packages, as our SAP Cloud ERP is the most transformational one.

However, if the new customer might be looking for more tailored-to-fit functionality—a very flexible system in which they maintain the governance of the system while SAP supports operations—the Cloud ERP Package can be offered after the review with the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment.

Customer Journey – GROW with SAP – Final Destination SAP Business Suite via SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages

As indicated before to make the most of all the components included in these SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages, the SAP Activate Methodology has been enhanced, and there is now a new roadmap available for provisioning SAP Business Suite Packages.

 

So, what about the other SAP Business Suite packages—SAP Strategic Procurement, SAP Core HR, and SAP CX?

These packages were designed based on personas. They provide our customers with defined functional capabilities within our core applications portfolio, data, and Business AI for a specific line of business. However, in combination with the Cloud ERP Private Package or the SAP Finance & SAP Supply Chain Management Package, they can offer even greater business benefits.

So, as in the example above, if an SAP ERP 6.0 customer is also running a legacy SAP ERP HCM system, they can adopt the new package for SAP Core HR to run SAP SuccessFactors and help them manage strategic human resources with solutions like SuccessFactors Employee Central, SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll, SuccessFactors Time Tracking, etc. SAP SuccessFactors is the next-generation cloud HR product, and this is where we are recommending our customers to move.

If the SAP ERP 6.0 customer is running a legacy SAP SRM 7.0 or any other legacy system to manage strategic sourcing, contract management, or is looking to implement these capabilities, they can choose SAP Strategic Procurement—an integrated solution bundle for managing the source-to-contract process through sourcing, contract management, supplier lifecycle, and performance management. Included solutions are: SAP Ariba Sourcing, SAP Ariba Contracts, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance.

If the SAP ERP 6.0 customer is running a legacy SAP CRM 7.0 or any other legacy system to manage comprehensive sales management, service management, or marketing capabilities, then the SAP CX Package (to be delivered in Q3 2025) can help the customer leverage the latest CX portfolio, such as SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud.

All Business Suite Packages that are available to existing on-premises SAP ERP 6.0 customers through the RISE with SAP customer journey

The same availability of SAP Business Suite Packages can be provided to a new SAP customer to complement the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management Packages.

All Business Suite Packages that are available to new SAP customers through the GROW with SAP customer journey

As indicated before, the new SAP Business Suite is not just a harmonization of a release and maintenance schedule of SAP’s portfolio of solutions. It’s a transformation engine that helps customers create rapid cycles of innovation end-to-end and continuous improvement as a service. In this regard, SAP is planning to make running the SAP Business Suite easier for customers and is planning to manage the integration of components. Early next year, SAP plans to begin offering SAP Cloud ERP + SAP Core HR managed integration as a service and will continue to introduce more in the future. Of course, these plans are subject to change.

We believe the new SAP Business Suite will help our customers gain more business outcomes by unlocking value and resilience at scale by combining core applications, data and business AI.

I would like to thank my colleagues, Daniel Kesenheimer, Elena Tewari, Matt Emmert & Marcus Venth, for their review and feedback on this blog.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

entry.title: Unlock Your Business Transformation with the Integrated Toolchain
entry.content:
In early 2025, SAP unveiled the new SAP Business Suite, marking a transformative era in modern enterprise management.
By combining artificial intelligence, data, and applications, SAP Business Suite empowers organizations to unlock innovation, drive operational excellence, and create differentiated business value.

Whether you're an existing SAP ERP customer or new to SAP solutions, transitioning to the SAP Business Suite is a significant step. At SAP, we've had the privilege of guiding many customers through their transformation journeys—experience that led to the creation of a structured, repeatable framework: the RISE with SAP Methodology.

This Methodology contains three main elements:

  • The Standardized framework: A structured path based on best practices roadmaps with recommendations, guidelines, and checkpoints for each step of your journey.
  • The Integrated toolchain: Tools to enhance your productivity, accelerate your project timelines, improve quality, and promote seamless, cross-team collaboration.
  • Expert guidance: SAP and qualified partners who get you up and running with a predictable scope and implementation timeline during your entire transformation journey.

In this blog we focus on the integrated toolchain, providing the right integrated tools to support the entire migration process with greater ease and efficiency. And we’re continuously enhancing these tools—adding new capabilities and embedding AI to further accelerate and simplify your transformation.

 

Consistent data. Extended by partners. Enabled by AI.

We learned that transformation success depends on more than just a single tool to support individual steps in the journey. Furthermore, it requires:

  • Consistent data throughout the transformation project to align decisions, processes, and outcomes –
  • A rich set of integrated tools extended by partners who bring specific expertise and tools to support our customers on their transformation journey
  • AI-enabled intelligence will be omnipresent along the integrated toolchain to support customers, consultants and architects to be more productive during the transformation

All of this combines the Integrated Toolchain

 

 

Together, these principles set the foundation for a successful and effective transformation.

SAPs integrated toolchain is designed to help our customers along the transformation journey with fully connected and integrated tools.

1.     Consistent data flow throughout your journey

The RISE with SAP Methodology provides a clear, structured approach to transformation utilizing the standardized framework. The Integrated Toolchain enables and accelerates this journey from end to end — combining tools that support each critical stage with sharing data along the process.

Let’s have a look on the journey, the individual tasks and how the toolchain will help these processes. In the overview graphics you can see that the different solutions in the Toolchain are not assigned to the different phases, but they support the transformation trough the full project and exchanging data to avoid double entry or inconsistencies. But let’s start along those phases to go through the transformation project and touch every solution

 

1.1 Discover & onboard

While new customers would directly start with the Digital Discovery Assessment to match their processes and priorities with needed capabilities - existing SAP ERP customers can first start to analyze their current processes based on real data with the help of SAP Signavio. This data is then handed over to SAP LeanIX to analyze and visualize your current architecture including dependencies, identifying risks and outdated systems.  This is the basis for designing the target architecture in the next phase.

As a next step, the Digital Discovery Assessment (DDA) helps define your business strategy and design the scope of the future solution by gathering customers’ requirements. Matching these requirements against Business Suite solutions proposes a list of solutions to fulfill all customers’ needs and additionally creates a customer project roadmap based on the customer’s needs. This is the basis for the customer's individual project roadmap.

1.2 Modernize & run

Based on the data of the Discover phase, SAP Lean IX helps to plan a future-ready architecture aligned with your business goals.

SAP Signavio supports designing and publishing new business process models which are then used by Cloud ALM to support implementations designing, testing and deploying the solutions. Additionally, Cloud ALM executes your roadmap using SAP Activate and best-practice content while tracking progress and managing quality with built-in checkpoints. It monitors and resolves issues proactively with analytics. This includes managing solution configuration, developing and integrating required extensions in adherence to the clean core compatible principals, based on the Business Technology Platform using no-code, low-code or pro-code as well as AI capabilities built in SAP Build. Partner solutions like SAP Test Automation by Tricentis help to design and run automated end-top-end tests to validate changes faster, increase process quality and reduce business risks. The SAP Business transformation center helps to clean and transform your business data of the former system into a AI ready data structures of the new landscape.

To maximize the adoption of new business processes, WalkMe in-app guidance and end-user training can assist to onboard and support users during a successful go-live, helping them use the new system efficiently.

1.3 Continuously innovate

After the successful go live SAP Cloud solution subscriptions include ongoing enhancements delivered through regular updates to enable continuous innovations delivering sustained business value to customers and their end-users.

The tools in the Integrated toolchain will help you shaping this process of continuous innovations:

SAP LeanIX identifies the latest architecture improvements and continuously mirrors the system architecture.

SAP Signavio updates its data to mirror the newest business processes based on the latest enhancements.

SAP Cloud ALM track progress and manage quality with built-in checkpoints and monitor and resolve issues proactively with analytics

WalkMe updates its guidance data to best enable and support users based on the latest enhancements.

SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Build enable additional process enhancements needed to differentiate your business from the competition - based on continuously enhanced or new extensions, built in a clean core compatible way to maintain and secure an upgradable core.

 

Want to see the integrated toolchain in action – just watch our video:

2.     Scale with partners to augment the toolchain

The integrated toolchain is open and extensible to partners who bring specific expertise and tools to support our customers on their transformation journey. Partners can build and integrate their own specialized tools, leveraging deep expertise or industry best practices to complement the core toolset. This openness ensures that every customer transformation project can benefit from proven methodologies, tailored accelerators, and innovative partner solutions—creating a flexible ecosystem that adapts to diverse business needs.

3.     Integrated Toolchain enabled by AI

We are adding AI capabilities into our integrated toolchain to boost your transformation efficiency and reduce duration, effort, and cost of transformation significantly.

As an example, SAP Lean IX gets new capabilities based on AI:

  1. Analyze as-is: Leverage the inventory builder to quickly build your inventory based on the AI analysis of unstructured data and the generation of LeanIX fact sheets
  2. Identify improvements: Leverage AI-assisted architecture guidance for continuous recommendations on where and how to optimize your enterprise architecture, with streamlined and actionable insights

On top we are working on the new Transition Guidance - SAP’s AI enabled application which acts as your pro-active encyclopedia deployed on Cloud ALM to

  • Connect the dots across tools, services and content to further increase usability and efficiency during all three phases (Discover & onboard, Modernize & Run, and Continuous innovations).
  • Provide personalized, system-based recommendations to accelerate fact-based decisions during transformation
  • Add a dialog driven conversational expert guidance based on Joule, giving advice along many advisory categories.

Clear business value

In a nutshell, the SAP Integrated Toolchain is built to deliver clear business value in 4 key dimensions:

30% cost reduction for the transformation project.

35% faster execution of the transformation leading to faster time to value.

70% increased business agility enabling customers to react faster to new market conditions to stay ahead of the competition.

40% Faster continuous innovation to benefit from newest capabilities supporting your business earlier.

 

 

Ready to Take the Next Step?

With RISE with SAP Methodology and the Integrated Toolchain, your transformation becomes a clear, guided journey — powered by best practices, intelligent tools, and continuous support.

Learn more: www.sap.com/rise-methodology

entry.title: How to Prepare for SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition Certification (with Sample Questions)
entry.content:
In this blog, I’ll share practical tips to help you to prepare and be able to pass the SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition certification (E_S4CPE_2405). While the post is especially helpful for those aiming to get certified, it also provides useful insights for SAP developers, Basis Admin, SAP Architects, Project Managers, and anyone who works daily in SAP ERP projects or operations.

You often start preparing for a certification and end up confused or lost, what are the right resources, and how deep should you go through different materials and references?

As a Microsoft and SAP Certified , I always tell new learners: preparing for a certification is like learning English as a second language—you want to be able to use it effectively in your day-to-day work, not become Shakespeare!
Here, I share the exact resources I use in my day-to-day role as an SAP Architect—drawing on over 20 years of hands-on experience in the SAP space. I’ve also included the key materials that can help you confidently prepare for the SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition.

I’ll be updating this post from time to time, since SAP technology and S/4HANA continue to evolve at a fast pace!

Being a successful SAP Solution consultant or SAP Expert requires a deep understanding of both on-premises and hyperscaler technologies, combined with hands-on experience from real customer projects. On top of that, strong expertise in SAP solutions is essential. Earning the SAP S/4 HANA certification is just the beginning of this journey.

This is the second blog of series, I’m going to share practical insights to help you prepare and succeed to achieve this as a goal.

 Why Get SAP Certified? Real-World Benefits:

  • Being certified earns immediate credibility customers, partners, and hiring managers are more likely to trust your knowledge and decisions.
  • SAP certification improves your chances of landing your desired role.
  • Certified professionals often qualify for higher rates, promotions, and leadership roles in SAP projects.
  • In some cases (e.g., security reviews, migration, SOC 2 documentation), certification adds weight to your approval or sign-off.
  • The annual certification renewal process ensures your knowledge stays current, especially with cloud solutions and SAP's evolving product roadmap.
  • Certification validates your hands-on skills and prepares you to deliver better results in real SAP implementations.
  • Certified professionals are more likely to be chosen for challenging or high-impact projects.
  • Certification gives you recognition within the broader SAP ecosystem.

 Exam Topics and Focus Areas

To pass the certification you’ll need a score of 72% or higher, SAP outlines the following key areas:

  • Introduction to Cloud Computing and SAP Cloud ERP Deployment Options (11% - 20%)
  • Data Migration and Business Process Testing (11% - 20%)
  • Implementing with a Cloud Mindset, Building the Team, and Conducting Fit-to-Standard Workshops (11% - 20%)
  • System Landscapes and Identity Access Management (11% - 20%)
  • Configuration and the SAP Fiori Launchpad (11% - 20%)
  • Extensibility, Integration, and Clean Core (11% - 20%)

 Key Areas of Study

To gain the knowledge required, focus on the following areas:

Before we start the sample questions , let me explain different types of SAP ERP provisioning.

SAP ECC was traditionally deployed in on-premises environments or customer data centres. With the introduction of S/4HANA, cloud provisioning options became available alongside traditional deployments.

Current Types of SAP ERP Deployment Methods

Cloud Editions

  • S/4HANA Cloud, public edition – Multi-tenant SaaS, fully managed by SAP.
  • S/4HANA Cloud, private edition – Single-tenant, SAP-managed infrastructure.

Note:  Although it runs on cloud infrastructure, S/4HANA Cloud, private edition shares more operational and management characteristics with on-premises deployments (greater customer control, customization, directly accessible via customer's network with no Egress cost, and lifecycle management).

On-Premises with Private Editions

  • S/4HANA Private Edition On-Premises managed by SAP (HEC – HANA Enterprise Cloud or ECS – Enterprise Cloud Service) – SAP hosts and operates the system in hyperscalers  on behalf of the customer.
  • S/4HANA Private Edition On-Premises at hyperscalers – Hosted by AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud but managed by the customer or a systems integrator.
  • S/4HANA Private Edition for Government (National security Service -NS2 ) – Specialized U.S.  deployment for government and defense, meeting the highest national security certifications in U.S and Canada .
  • S/4HANA On-Premises in customer data center – Fully customer-managed.
  • S/4HANA On-Premises via SAP certified partners – Deployed using appliances in a customer data center.

Note: RISE with SAP is not a deployment method , it is a bundle offering with one contract.

Legacy Options

  • SAP ECC in customer data center (on-premises) – Classic model, customer-managed.
  • SAP ECC at hyperscalers – Often a transitional step (Unicode migration, system prep) before moving to S/4HANA in cloud environment.

I've put together 15 sample questions to help you prepare for the exam. These questions are a bit more challenging than the ones you'll typically see on the actual test:

Sample Questions

  1. Which choice is the main used of Launchpad Content Manager? There are 2 correct answers to this question
    1. Manage technical catalogs
    2. Create custom business catalogs
    3. Perform mass changes on business catalogs
    4. Add or remove catalogs content references

  2. In an S/4HANA Private Edition implementation, which type of testing focuses on verifying that the overall system still works as expected after applying changes such as upgrades, patches, or configuration updates?
    1. Unit Test
    2. Business Process Test
    3. User Acceptance Test

entry.title: ATP vs Advanced ATP in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private edition 2023
entry.content:
Introduction

Choosing between ATP and Advanced ATP is a crucial decision for organizations seeking future-proof functionality. This guide outlines the key considerations for making the right choice and clarifies the limitations and future roadmap of each platform.

Understanding the Platforms

  • ATP (Advanced To Promise): ATP has served as a robust tool for threat detection and response. However, it is important to note that ATP will not be enhanced with new features going forward. Its existing capabilities will be maintained, but no future innovation.
  • Advanced ATP: Advanced ATP is designed with expanded functionality, incorporating more sophisticated threat analytics and response mechanisms. It benefits from ongoing development and regular introduction of new features to address emerging business challenges.

Key Differences

  • Feature Development: ATP will not receive additional features, while Advanced ATP will continue to evolve with new capabilities.
  • Integration: It is not possible to combine ATP and Advanced ATP functionalities. Each platform operates independently, and use of features from one cannot be merged with the other.

Advanced ATP functionalities

Product Availability Check (PAC)

  • It is possible to configure detailed verification scopes based on specific requirements or quantities.
  • Correlation of Schedule Line quantities in Sales Bill of Material
  • Zero Confirmation or full confirmation at End of Replenishment Lead Time by the configuration

Back Order Processing (BOP)

  • Configuration also enables the extension of prioritization capabilities, allowing users to tailor priority rules according to specific business requirements. By leveraging configurable settings, organizations can dynamically adjust how orders are prioritized during availability checks, ensuring that critical shipments or key customers receive preferential allocation when supply is limited.

Interactive Backorer Processing

  • User can manually change the strategy.

Business Process Scheduling (BPS)

  • Scheduling activities can be incorporated to enable comprehensive planning and management of timelines, allowing users to coordinate and optimize schedules effectively within the system.

Product Allocation Check (PAL)

  • A supply limit function enables users to define maximum available quantities, and configuration values can be conveniently uploaded directly from Excel files for efficient mass updates.

Supply Protection (SUP)

  • It is possible to set minimum supply limits.

Alternative Based Confirmation (ABC)

  • When product shortages occur, the system can automatically switch plants or substitute products based on pre-configured master data settings, ensuring that customer demands are fulfilled as efficiently as possible. This automated substitution functionality enhances flexibility and responsiveness by automatically identifying alternative supply sources or equivalent products, aligning with customer requirements even in the face of inventory constraints.

Dynamic third-party order processing

  • Triggering of third-party order processing (TPOP), where the requirement for ordered goods in a sales order are passed to a vendor (supplier) for direct shipment to the end customer.

ATP Analysis

  • First increment of an improved user experience when reviewing the availability check result in sales order processing:
  • SAP Fiori user experience (UX)
  • Cross-item overview on availability check result
  • Display confirmations including substitutes
  • Navigation to classic delivery proposal screen for non-subitem confirmations to allow proposal adjustments

Interactive ATP

  • With Review Availability Check Results (RACR), users have the ability to manually adjust the confirmed quantities as needed. This feature enables greater control and flexibility in managing order fulfillment, allowing adjustments to be made directly within the system based on changing supply conditions or operational requirements.

Supply creation-Based Confirmation (SBC)

  • In integration scenarios with PP-DS, support is provided for both Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP) and Support Block Planning within PP/DS, enabling sophisticated planning capabilities based on product characteristics and optimized scheduling through block planning methods.

Release for delivery (RefDy)

  • It is possible to manually adjust the allocated confirmed quantity during the creation of delivery documents, providing additional flexibility in the shipping process.

Advanced ATP Online help:

ATP Functionalities

Product Availability Check

  • Basic Product Availability check
  • Manually selection product
  • Manually plant selection changing
  • Simple transportation and shipment scheduling based on days (and hours)

Back Order Processing

  • Basic Backorder processing.
  • The available prioritization options are quite limited, restricted mainly to dates and shipping priority, and cannot be extended beyond these parameters.

ATP Online Help:

How to Choose

  • If your organization requires only the current feature set and stability, ATP may be sufficient. However, be aware that there will be no further feature enhancements.
  • If your organization needs advanced features and the flexibility to adapt to new threats, Advanced ATP is the recommended choice. Its ongoing development ensures access to the latest tools.
  • Consider your long-term strategy. For organizations aiming for future scalability and innovation, Advanced ATP will be more appropriate.
  • Advanced ATP requires an additional license beyond S/4HANA. Please contact your our sales guys about the detail.

Limitations

  • You cannot use ATP and Advanced ATP functionalities together. Selection of one platform means you rely exclusively on its feature set.
  • Migrating from ATP to Advanced ATP may require reconfiguration, so plan the transition carefully if you anticipate future needs for newer features.

Conclusion

When deciding between ATP and Advanced ATP, assess your organization’s future goals. If long-term growth and adaptability to new threats are priorities, Advanced ATP is the optimal selection. For static requirements with no need for new functionalities, ATP remains a viable, though limited, option. The inability to combine both platforms’ features underscores the importance of a clear, strategic choice.
